properties.description: If marmots store more food in Fall, it signifies a long winter.

Park rangers in collaboration with French citizen scientists from OSI-Panthera conduct wildlife monitoring expeditions in Naryn National Reserve. Monitors use GPS equipment, binoculars, and trap cameras to count animals.

Park rangers in Salkyn Tor State Park conduct wildlife monitoring in collaboration with the state hunting department. Tracking animal populations helps the government determine how many hunting permits to issue for the coming year.
Horse mares may give birth prematurely, sacrificing their offspring to conserve their health and prepare for a long winter.

In Soviet times, Oct. 1 was the set date to bring sheep together to begin mating. This would signal the time to move from high summer pastures to vilages, to provide shelter for the lambs from the coming cold and wolves.

Higher anthills observed in nature means that the coming winter will be longer and have more snow. Building a larger anthill allows the mound to retain more heat, helping ants survive a longer winter.
If marmots hibernate early, the coming winter will be cold and long.
Wolves will begin to cross the river nearby town when the river freezes in winter and they are hungry enough to risk it.
A dry winter is predicted by coniferious trees not dropping many nuts or seeds in the preceding year.

In Soviet times, Dec. 1 was the fixed date sheep were sent to Sakman, a special corralling area and stable. This signified the change of activities to winter duties, such as preparing animal fodder and removing most animals from remote pastures.

Herders check nearby Tokomon mountain to gauge water levels for the coming summer. From this vantage point, they observe how much snow has fallen over the pasture and its depth to estimate how much meltwater will be available in summer.

After checking the mountain pastures, local level pasture user committees hold public meetings to plan, share information, and distribute pamphlets. These committees are responsible for collecting fees which are to be used to maintain the pasture through road construction and reforestation.

The spring melt causes issues of dirty drinking water in village drinking sources fed by mountain run-off. The vast amounts of water melting can capture soil and trace metals from upstream sources and wash it into the main streams. In individual villages, households living upstream have an important role in ensuring the water source is not polluted.

Park rangers in Salkyn Tor State Park conduct wildlife in collaboration with the state hunting department. Tracking animal populations in the spring helps the authorities determine how the wildlife has weathered the past winter.
A local legend of seeing two white birds taking flight together signifies the time to move from low-lying winter pastures to high summer pastures.

Horses are brought together and yoked near the household yurts in the pastures. This is to keep them close to the smoke of the household fire, which smokes away "gogun" insects. These mosquito-like insects are thought to be able to prevent proper lactating by horses if they sting them. Herders depend on the milk products of their horses and other animals to eat and sell for additional income.
Villagers with disposable income give their animals to herders to bring to high pastures. This signifies a shift to the summer season, when the high pastures are accessible.
If few mice are spotted in the fields during spring, the coming summer will be dry.

Herders will collect or buy firewood for the entire high summer pasture season at this time. Ensuring the proper collection and usage of only dead wood is critical to protect the new spring growth at this time. Park rangers in Salkyn Tor are experimenting with grafted trees that grow faster than the traditional Tien Shan fir, to help alleviate wood supply issues.
In August, traditional medicine practitioners will collect herbs from riverbanks and nearby hills.

At the peak of their animals' strength, herders will gather to play traditional games such as kok-buru in the high pastures. These events are a way for herders to share information, as well as to take stock of the health of their herds.

In exceptionally hot summers, grazing animals will move early from the pastures back to the villages. This causes problems as the animals graze the planted crops of the villagers, which are not always fenced off.
